awd_titl_txt: Ice Dynamics at the Intersection of the West and East Antarctic Ice Sheets
awd_abstract_narration:
The response of the Antarctic ice sheet to climate change is a central issue in projecting global sea-level rise. While much attention is focused on the ongoing rapid changes at the coastal margin of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet, obtaining records of past ice-sheet and climate change is the only way to constrain how an ice sheet changes over millennial timescales. Whether the West Antarctic Ice Sheet collapsed during the last interglacial period (~130,000 to 116,000 years ago), when temperatures were slightly warmer than today, remains a major unsolved problem in Antarctic glaciology. Hercules Dome is an ice divide located at the intersection of the East Antarctic and West Antarctic ice sheets. It is ideally situated to record the glaciological and climatic effects of changes in the West Antarctic Ice Sheet. This project will establish whether Hercules Dome experienced major changes in flow due to changes in the elevation of the two ice sheets. The project will also ascertain whether Hercules Domes is a suitable site from which to recover climate records from the last interglacial period.  These records could be used to determine whether the West Antarctic Ice Sheet collapsed during that period. The project will support two early-career researchers and train students at the University of Washington. Results will be communicated through outreach programs in coordination the Ice Drilling Project Office, the University of Washington's annual Polar Science Weekend in Seattle, and art-science collaboration.

This project will develop a history of ice dynamics at the intersection of the East and West Antarctic ice sheets, and ascertain whether the site is suitable for a deep ice-coring operation.  Ice divides provide a unique opportunity to assess the stability of past ice flow.  The low deviatoric stresses and non-linearity of ice flow causes an arch (a "Raymond Bump") in the internal layers beneath a stable ice divide.  This information can be used to determine the duration of steady ice flow. Due to the slow horizontal ice-flow velocities, ice divides also preserve old ice with internal layering that reflects past flow conditions caused by divide migration. Hercules Dome is an ice divide that is well positioned to retain information of past variations in the geometry of both the East and West Antarctic Ice Sheets. This dome is also the most promising location at which to recover an ice core that can be used to determine whether the West Antarctic Ice Sheet collapsed during the last interglacial period. Limited ice-penetrating radar data collected along a previous scientific surface traverse indicate well-preserved englacial stratigraphy and evidence suggestive of a Raymond Bump, but the previous survey was not sufficiently extensive to allow thorough characterization or determination of past changes in ice dynamics. This project will conduct a dedicated survey to map the englacial stratigraphy and subglacial topography as well as basal properties at Hercules Dome. The project will use ground-based ice-penetrating radar to 1) image internal layers and the ice-sheet basal interface, 2) accurately measure englacial attenuation, and 3) determine englacial vertical strain rates. The radar data will be combined with GPS observations for detailed topography and surface velocities and ice-flow modeling to constrain the basal characteristics and the history of past ice flow.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This primary goal of this project was to develop a history of ice dynamics at the intersection of the East and West Antarctic ice sheets and ascertain whether the site is suitable for a deep ice-coring operation. Although much attention has recently focused on the ongoing rapid changes at the coastal margin of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet, obtaining records of past ice-sheet and climate change is the only way to constrain how an ice sheet changes over millennial timescales. Whether the West Antarctic Ice Sheet collapsed during the last interglacial period (approximately 130,000 to 116,000 years ago), when temperatures were slightly warmer than today, remains a major unsolved problem in Antarctic glaciology. Hercules Dome is an ice divide located at the intersection of the East Antarctic and West Antarctic ice sheets. It is ideally situated to record the glaciological and climatic effects of changes in the West Antarctic Ice Sheet, and an ice core from this location will contain a record of whether the West Antarctic Ice Sheet collapsed during the most-recent previous interglacial period. This project used a variety of geophysical surveying techniques and ice-flow modeling to assess the past ice-flow conditions at Hercules Dome and determined a propitious site for a future ice core.

Our geophysical surveys had three primary goals: (1) mapping bedrock topography of the region, (2) mapping ice-sheet internal layers to determine past ice-flow patterns and snow accumulation rate, and (3) using radar interferometry to determine current englacial velocities and compare them to past velocities inferred from ice-flow modeling. To meet these goals, we deployed four ground-penetrating radar systems at Hercules Dome: an impulse ice-penetrating radar designed to map internal layer geometry and bedrock topography immediately beneath the radar, a higher-frequency impulse radar optimized for mapping shallow ice structure, a phase sensitive radar array that can map internal layers and bedrock topography in three dimensions (producing elevation maps of the landscape beneath the ice that are similar to those produced by terrestrial laser scanning or structure-from-motion photogrammetry), and a stationary phase-sensitive radar sounder that can measure the vertical motion (and, hence, vertical velocity) of ice-sheet internal layers between repeat radar measurements. These surveys revealed a complex high-relief alpine glacier landscape, similar in scale to Yosemite Valley, beneath the eastern part of Hercules Dome. The western part of Hercules Dome is less complex, with generally continuous bed conformal internal layering overlying a more subtle topographic ridge, which may locally stabilize ice flow. These data were used as input to two modeling approaches: a kinematic ice-flow model to simulate internal layer geometry and ice age, and a reduced marine outlet glacier model to estimate interior response to changes at the ice-sheet margin over longer timescales. Our geophysical data and modeling results indicate that eastern Hercules Dome has hosted rapidly flowing ice in the past and may still respond relatively quickly to changes at the ice-sheet margin. Western Hercules Dome is more stable and is a promising prospective ice-core site, potentially hosting ice that is about 130,000 years old about 50 m above the base of the ice sheet. 

The project provided eight early-career researchers (graduate students or engineers just starting their first permanent position) their first opportunities to participate in Antarctic research and conduct scientific fieldwork in Antarctica. Five graduate students who participated in this project have completed their PhDs and moved onto new positions. Results from this project have been published in five peer-reviewed papers (four led by graduate students), spanning the full range of disciplinary journals from specific (Annals of Glaciology) to high profile (Nature Geoscience). Two additional publications are in final stages of preparation for submission to peer-reviewed journals. Six datasets (ice-penetrating radar data and results, water isotope deposition model simulations) have been published in open-access repositories (NSF-funded United States Antarctic Program Data Center) and are freely available to the scientific community and public for further analysis. This project also contributed to development of an open-source ground-penetrating radar software package (ImpDAR, available on GitHub) that can be used to view, process, and analyze these data. These data are also being incorporated into the NSF-supported Open Polar Radar project, which freely releases ice-penetrating radar data and software to the scientific community and the public. Finally, this project resulted in selection of an ice-core site, which will be the location of the next US-led deep ice-core project in Antarctica.
